trans-unit.source: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.

trans-unit.source: There is generally not a one-to-one mapping of functionality, though: either platform may have more or less functionality than its counterpart in a namespace or class.
trans-unit.target: There is generally not a one-to-one mapping of functionality, though: either platform may have more or less functionality than its counterpart in a namespace or class.

trans-unit.source: The mapping table will help you when you're working in a UWP project and you're re-using source code from a Windows Phone Silverlight project.
trans-unit.target: The mapping table will help you when you're working in a UWP project and you're re-using source code from a Windows Phone Silverlight project.

trans-unit.source: There are differences in the names of namespaces and classes (including UI controls) between the two platforms.
trans-unit.target: There are differences in the names of namespaces and classes (including UI controls) between the two platforms.

trans-unit.source: In many cases, it's as easy as changing a namespace name and then your code will compile.
trans-unit.target: In many cases, it's as easy as changing a namespace name and then your code will compile.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, a class or API name has changed as well as the namespace name.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, a class or API name has changed as well as the namespace name.

trans-unit.source: Other times, the mapping takes a bit more work, and in rare cases requires a change in approach.
trans-unit.target: Other times, the mapping takes a bit more work, and in rare cases requires a change in approach.

trans-unit.source: **How to use the table: ** First, search for the name of the class you're using.
trans-unit.target: **How to use the table: ** First, search for the name of the class you're using.

trans-unit.source: Classes are listed whenever the mapping is more complicated than simply changing the namespace name.
trans-unit.target: Classes are listed whenever the mapping is more complicated than simply changing the namespace name.

trans-unit.source: If your class is not listed, then the mapping is just a namespace change.
trans-unit.target: If your class is not listed, then the mapping is just a namespace change.

trans-unit.source: So, find your class's namespace name and you'll find the equivalent UWP namespace name.
trans-unit.target: So, find your class's namespace name and you'll find the equivalent UWP namespace name.

trans-unit.source: Your class will be in that namespace.
trans-unit.target: Your class will be in that namespace.

trans-unit.source: If your namespace is not listed, then its name has not changed.
trans-unit.target: If your namespace is not listed, then its name has not changed.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Windows 10 supports much more of the .NET Framework than a Windows Phone Store app does.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Windows 10 supports much more of the .NET Framework than a Windows Phone Store app does.

trans-unit.source: For example, Windows 10 has several System.ServiceModel.\* namespaces as well as System.Net, System.Net.NetworkInformation, and System.Net.Sockets.
trans-unit.target: For example, Windows 10 has several System.ServiceModel.\* namespaces as well as System.Net, System.Net.NetworkInformation, and System.Net.Sockets.

trans-unit.source: Also, in a Windows 10 app, you will benefit from .NET Native, which an ahead-of-time compilation technology that converts MSIL into natively-runnable machine code.
trans-unit.target: Also, in a Windows 10 app, you will benefit from .NET Native, which an ahead-of-time compilation technology that converts MSIL into natively-runnable machine code.

trans-unit.source: .NET Native apps start faster, use less memory, and use less battery than their MSIL counterparts.
trans-unit.target: .NET Native apps start faster, use less memory, and use less battery than their MSIL counterparts.

trans-unit.source: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library are built into the default Styles of the common controls.
trans-unit.target: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library are built into the default Styles of the common controls.

trans-unit.source: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.
trans-unit.target: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.

trans-unit.source: [**ItemsWrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298849) and [**WrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227717) can be used in the items panel template of an items control.
trans-unit.target: [**ItemsWrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298849) and [**WrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227717) can be used in the items panel template of an items control.

trans-unit.source: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.
trans-unit.target: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.

trans-unit.source: [**ItemsWrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298849) and [**WrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227717) can be used in the items panel template of an items control.
trans-unit.target: [**ItemsWrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298849) and [**WrapGrid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227717) can be used in the items panel template of an items control.

trans-unit.source: As a workaround, use conditional compilation and define a custom symbol.
trans-unit.target: As a workaround, use conditional compilation and define a custom symbol.

trans-unit.source: Or you may be able to engineer a workaround using the [IsAttached](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/e299w87h.aspx) property.
trans-unit.target: Or you may be able to engineer a workaround using the [IsAttached](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/e299w87h.aspx) property.

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but some properties are missing (for example, IsReadOnly)
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but some properties are missing (for example, IsReadOnly)

trans-unit.source: **System.Net.DownloadProgressChangedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**
trans-unit.target: **System.Net.DownloadProgressChangedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**

trans-unit.source: These classes are still supported, but some properties are missing.
trans-unit.target: These classes are still supported, but some properties are missing.

trans-unit.source: Partial support, but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).
trans-unit.target: Partial support, but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).

trans-unit.source: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httprequestmessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP request.
trans-unit.target: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httprequestmessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP request.

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

trans-unit.source: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).
trans-unit.target: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).

trans-unit.source: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpresponsemessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP response.
trans-unit.target: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpresponsemessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP response.

trans-unit.source: Still supported, except for the constructor.
trans-unit.target: Still supported, except for the constructor.

trans-unit.source: **System.Net.OpenReadCompletedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**
trans-unit.target: **System.Net.OpenReadCompletedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but use the SocketErrorCode property instead of ErrorCode.
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but use the SocketErrorCode property instead of ErrorCode.

trans-unit.source: **System.Net.UploadProgressChangedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**
trans-unit.target: **System.Net.UploadProgressChangedEventArgs** class, and similar classes related to **System.Net.WebClient**

trans-unit.source: Partial support (a different set of properties), but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).
trans-unit.target: Partial support (a different set of properties), but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).

trans-unit.source: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httprequestmessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP request.
trans-unit.target: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httprequestmessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP request.

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

trans-unit.source: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).
trans-unit.target: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the [**HttpClient**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298639) class (or [System.Net.Http.HttpClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpclient(v=vs.118).aspx)).

trans-unit.source: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpresponsemessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP response.
trans-unit.target: These APIs use [System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.net.http.httpresponsemessage.aspx) to represent an HTTP response.

trans-unit.source: A custom method that returns the appropriate type.
trans-unit.target: A custom method that returns the appropriate type.

trans-unit.source: Still supported, but use ReadAsync() and WriteAsync() instead of BeginRead()/EndRead() and BeginWrite()/EndWrite().
trans-unit.target: Still supported, but use ReadAsync() and WriteAsync() instead of BeginRead()/EndRead() and BeginWrite()/EndWrite().
